Bradford's Law of Scattering .A Vickery, B.C. These authors collected a large number of references to a certain subject, and arranged the periodicals in which the references occurred in order of decreasing productivity.  Thus for applied geophysics they found (loc. cit., p. 112) 1 periodical containing 93 references, 1 containing 86, 4 containing 16, 49 containing 2, and 169 containing only 1 reference.  They then made cumulative totals for the two sets of figures, so that in the T most productive periodicals there occurred in all R references.  Bradford then plotted log T against R and his curves are reproduced as B and C in Fig. 1.  An exactly similar procedure for periodical references borrowed by Butterwick resulted in curve A.
